Error.Description: FILEPI already in effect. Another FILEPI may not be initiated until current one expires or a FILEPI 0 or PI 0 is executed.
A FILEPI referenced one or more unopened files.
A FILEPI was executed against a file that has been opened with record locking.
A READ using the 'LK' suffix has been executed for a file that is not open in SHARE mode.
A READ using 'LK' suffix has been executed for a file that is open without record locking support.
A file in the TRANSACTION START file list is not open.
A FILEPI operation specified more than 50 managed files while accessing a SUNDM data manager.
A FILE variable opened in a record locking mode is included in the TRANSACTION START {file lock list}.
The specified program could not be found.
Bad common file alignment. Common files are specified in the new program that were not specified (in those same positions in the UDA) in the original program.
Incompatible program. Both programs must be compiled with compatible compiler versions.
Invalid program file format. Re-compile the program.
Insufficient memory resources exist to load the program.
Could not create ROLLOUT file. Check rights, space utilization and number of file handles available.
Common data misalignment or problem with global data variables where the data types and size must be the same.
Global data area overflow.
Misaligned common. Module and variable address are returned as additional information in the error variable.
Invalid data type encountered (Possible data corruption). Module and variable address are returned as additional information in the error variable.
Global variable declared size different from already loaded variable. Module and variable address are returned as additional information in the error variable.
Global variable defined as different type from already loaded variable. Module and variable address are returned as additional information in the error variable.
Global array variable has a different number of variables from currently loaded array variable. Module and variable address are returned as additional information in the error variable.
Invalid global file control word for a FILELIST. Global memory has been corrupted for unexplained reasons.
Unable to establish a global FILELIST primary file. Insufficient memory.
Null variable used for program name or name too long.
Unable to maintain spooling across program chain, spooling disabled.
LOADMOD module may not be loaded or a procedure is not defined within a specified LOADMOD module.
Unable to locate object file or procedure name.
Unable to translate object code file byte order to proper format. One possible cause is corrupted object code file.

Insufficient allocated memory available to load the module. Use the '-mNNNNNN' runtime command line option to increase the allocated memory. The value specified is in bytes. If the option is not specified, the runtime default is 1,024,000 bytes.
The minimum runtime version specified in the object code file is incompatible with the runtime version executing.
The load module forward/reverse order format is invalid for the runtime being used. This error could indicate that the object code file is corrupted.
Unable to seek to locations within a load module. The likely cause is an object code file with incorrect information in the header.
Unable to read a specified number of bytes from the load module. Possible causes are a module that was compiled with errors or a corrupted module is being used.
External name null.
Internal name greater than fifty (50) bytes long.
User procedure not provided.
CALLS name variable null.

CALLS procedure not found. Possible causes are the routine does not exist in any loaded module or the case for the routine name does not match the name of the routine name compiled into the load module.
Unable to resolve external procedure.
Unable to locate or open load module in read only mode.
An invalid or corrupted program data variable was detected as a LOADMOD module was being loaded.
When using dynamic load modules, there is insufficient memory available to load the module.
Insufficient memory available to load the Auto Load DIM variables. The Auto Load DIM variables are compiled into a program when the 'DIM ^size' syntax is used explicitly or implicitly in a program.
An invalid or corrupted program data variable was detected as a program module was being loaded.
The data variable translation to reverse the byte order failed. The extended error information give a relative translation data offset to help identify a range where the error occurs.
Data variable translation failed. An error occurred while processing the program data variables in the UDA.

The variable specified in a SCRNRESTORE, STATERESTORE, TRAPRESTORE, or WINRESTORE statement does not contain the exact amount of information required. Also, a TRAPRESTORE must be performed in the same program that performed the TRAPSAVE.
TRAPREST - Variable logical length too small.
TRAPREST - Variable time stamp invalid for mainline program in use.
TRAPREST - Data invalid causing trap identifier sequencing error.
TRAPREST - Data invalid for error trap identifier.
TRAPREST - Data invalid for function key trap identifier.
TRAPREST - Data invalid causing undetermined identifier.
TRAPREST - Variable logical length invalid for traps restored.
SCRNREST - Variable logical length invalid.
STATEREST - Variable logical length invalid.
WINREST - Variable logical length invalid.
Numeric field content error in numeric operation.
The ARRAY index specified was not within the defined range. May also indicate invalid Pointer if it occurs within an I/O list.
Array index value out of range.
Uninitialized pointer reference.
Variable type mismatch in parameterized CALL list. A F05 error can occur when an invalid array pointer type is encountered in a variable list.

A PROCEDURE was called with a FILE, IFILE, AFILE, or PFILE and the corresponding receiving xFILE was already open. If a file is passed to a PROCEDURE, the receiving file declaration must be closed at the time of the CALL.
The DIM variable logical string size for the user specified translation table in a LOWERCASE/UPPERCASE instruction must be 256.
Either the whole digit parameter or the fraction digit parameter is negative for a NFORMAT instruction.

An invalid destination variable has been detected for an IMPLODE or EXPLODE statement. This error occurs when the source variable in an EXPLODE operation is the same as a dest variable. Also, this error occurs in an EXPLODE statement if an object is in the destination list and the delimiter parameter is null. In an IMPLODE statement, this error occurs if an invalid object is detected in the source list.
The MODE value for a HASH instruction is invalid. The acceptable values must be zero (0) to four (3) or one hundred (100) to one hundred four (104).

A LABEL execution pointer is referencing an EXTERNAL load module declaration and it is being used in a flow control instruction that does not support an EXTERNAL instruction. For example, a GOTO instruction does not support an EXTERNAL reference.
A FINDDIR instruction was unable to create a DMAKE buffer for for a destination DIM pointer.
Invalid UTF-8 characters are being moved or stored into a NCHAR or NINIT variable. The NCHAR and NINIT variable can only contain valid UTF-8 characters.
Unable to uppercase a UTF-8 string.
NCHAR and DIM variable types are not allowed for the PL/B instruction.
Out for memory to perform format operation.
Requested file/device unavailable. Occurs only in spool traps, otherwise spool waits until the file/device is released. The file/device is already locked (in use) by another process.
PRINT operation attempted on an unopened file.
PRINT operation did not write out the requested number of characters. Possible file space full or hardware malfunction.
File space full writing to spool file.
Error closing spool file.
Specified file/device could not be opened/created or a prtopen dialog box was canceled. Insufficient access privileges to the file/device or ead-only file/device.
Spool file name is null.
Internal closing error (system error).
Unable to allocate necessary spool file buffer.
Spool device not available at time of PRINT.
Spool device became not available during a PRINT operation.
Invalid PFILE declaration for PRTPAGE instruction.
Invalid font specified for PRTPAGE instruction.
Unable to allocate memory.
Unable to locate font or font not valid for requested device.
Unable to create working font.
Font in single quotes not terminated.
Font name not valid internal name or does not start with '>' character.
Invalid options in parenthesis.
Invalid options string not terminated properly.
Invalid options string not terminated properly.
Invalid font name extra data at end of name.
When generating a PDF file local to the PLBSERVE application, the server runtime could not retrieve font information from a PLBCLIENT FONT object because the PLBCLIENT version is older than 9.6A.
Unable to print picture for PRTPAGE instruction. Normal cause would be insufficient memory.
PRINT statement used a *{tab} where the {tab} value is less than 1 or greater than 512.
Spool File could not be locked for exclusive use.
An invalid file name was encountered.
Standard spool file open or prep dialog was canceled.
Invalid options specified for SPLOPEN instruction.
Error writing advanced print spool file.
Error reading advanced print spool file.
Invalid advanced print spool file.
An invalid print control command was encountered while processing a PRTPLAY spool file. The spool file has been corrupted.
Invalid PRTPLAY spool file identifier was detected. Either the file was not generated as a PRTOPEN spool file or it has been corrupted.
The PRTPLAY spool file version is invalid. This error would occur if an older runtime accessed a spool file generated by a newer runtime.

The PRTPLAY spool file is in an incomplete state. A PRTOPEN spool file was created and started but the spooling operation was not completed properly. This could occur if a program was terminated prematurely while generating a spool file.
Out of memory creating print image.
Unable to create print preview window.
Windows device invalid for PLBSERVE. This indicates that you cannot print to a Windows printer on the server side.
An error has occurred processing a PDF file.
An '*ATTACH' syntax error has occurred. Check the fields being used the '*ATTACH' data string.
An '*INFO' syntax error has occurred. Check the fields being used in the '*INFO' data string.
An '*ENCRYPT' syntax error has occurred. Check the fields being used in the '*ENCRYPT' data string.
An internal syntax error has occurred. An invalid PDF print control has been encountered. The only supported PDF print controls are *ATTACH, *ENCRYPT, and *INFO.
A processing error has been encountered for the *ATTACH PDF print control. The specified attachment file to be put into a PDF can not be found.
A processing error has been encountered for the *INFO PDF print control. The user information could not be added to a PDF file.

A processing error has been encountered for the *ENCRYPT PDF print control. An error occurred when attempting to encrypt the PDF file. Make sure that the *ENCRYPT PDF control is executed before any data is output to a PDF file.
Template control string error has occurred.

An error has occurred opening or reading the PDF file specified by the *Template control 'F' parameter. Also, this subcode occurs if an unsupported PDF object or format is encountered processing the PDF template file data.
An error has occurred processing the PRTPAGE *PICT control to directly embed JPG image data directly into the Sunbelt PDF 'pdf:' file.
Invalid image file name. Null name not allowed.
Invalid image file name. Length of path and name too long.
Invalid image file name! Blank name not allowed.
Unable open image file name.
Invalid *PICT Image file size.
Unable to read all of the *PICT Image data.
Unable to allocate memory for image buffer.
Invalid image type.
Unable to print image.
Requested resource not found during CREATE of an object. Resource DLL cannot be open in two (2) programs at the same time.
Requested PICT or MOVIE file not found during CREATE of an object.

Windows system error during CREATE of an object. Possible causes of this error could be the lack of available memory, the lack of system resources to allow creation of the object, improper data in variable for CREATE or points to a DLL that does not exist. If the error was on a CREATE DIALOG instruction, an additional subcode is provided in the form of 'nnmm' where nn is the dialog item being processed and mm is the actual error.
During a CREATE DIALOG instruction, an equal sign or colon was expected but not found.
During a CREATE DIALOG instruction, a single quote' was missing on a name.
During a CREATE DIALOG instruction, out of memory.
During a CREATE DIALOG instruction, a position t:b:l:r was malformed.
During a CREATE DIALOG instruction, the dialog type was not MODAL, MODELESS, or PROGRESS.
During a CREATE DIALOG instruction, the dialog POS or ABSPOS values were malformed.
During a CREATE DIALOG instruction, an undefined Dialog string operation encountered.
During a CREATE DIALOG instruction, unable to load an ICON.
During a CREATE DIALOG instruction, too many items in Dialog.
During a CREATE instruction, a comma separator is missing.
During a CREATE instruction, a PLB FORM value is too large for a .NET data variable.
During a CREATE instruction, a PLB FORM negative value is invalid for the .NET data type.
The screen dimensions are too small to allow an object to be created.
A CREATE instruction must be executed for an object before an ACTIVATE instruction may be used or the object is specified.
Insufficient memory is available to perform operation.
A dialog number not associated with a POPUPMENU or a DATALIST dialog item was specified for a DELETITEM instruction.
Invalid font specified.
Unable to allocate memory.
Unable to locate font or font not valid for requested device.
Unable to create working font.
Font in single quotes not terminated.
Font name not valid internal name or does not start with '>' character.
Invalid options in parenthesis.
Invalid options string not terminated properly.
Invalid options string not terminated properly.
Invalid font name extra data at end of name.
Too many MODAL dialogs have been activated at the same time. Only ten MODAL dialogs may be activated in a nested manner.

Deactivation of nested MODAL dialog is not being performed in reverse order to activation order. When MODAL dialogs are activated in a nested manner, they must be deactivated in the reverse order of activation.

WINAPI error where the function specified in the PROFILE declaration could not be found. Make sure the spelling of the API function name is correct. If the name appears to be correct, the cause may be that the function is a UNICODE enabled function that requires that the API function name has a character 'A' or 'W' appended to it. A UNICODE enabled function may be determined when a parameter of the API function is a string variable. The 'A' character indicates that the string parameters contain ASCIIZ data. The 'W' indicates that the string parameters contain UNICODE string data.

WINAPI error where an invalid parameter was passed in for the function specified in the PROFILE declaration. Verify that the variable type specified in the PROFILE declaration is consistent with the required parameters of the API function.

WINAPI error where an invalid result variable was assigned for the function specified in the PROFILE declaration. Verify that the variable type specified in the PROFILE declaration is consistent with the return variable of the API function.
WINAPI error where the DLL module name specified in the PROFILE declaration was not loaded or is invalid.
Invalid tab stop value in a DATALIST object.
The DATALIST is full.
The COMBOBOX is full.
A MODELESS dialog cannot be activated on top of a MODAL dialog.
The FORMLOAD operation failed.
During a FORMLOAD, invalid form creation data for window object was encountered.
During a FORMLOAD, an invalid form window object was encountered.
During a FORMLOAD, unable to identify a form object.

During a FORMLOAD, an invalid object type found for a form.

During a FORMLOAD, unable to read form name data.

During a FORMLOAD, the form must be an objects-only form.
Too many items in COLLECTION.
A WINDOW object specified for the PARENTWIN property has not been created.
Operation being performed that is not supported for PLBCE runtime.
Specified property does not exist for object.

Too many parameters have been specified for an object method or a WINAPI instruction. For the WINAPI instruction, any API function parameter type requiring an INT8 PLB data type counts as two (2) parameters toward the maximum of twenty (20) parameters supported.
There is a problem with a method name, with one of the parameter names, or parameter names are not allowed at all.
Invalid parameter type specified for a method.
Invalid parameter type specified for a method.
Required parameter is missing from method parameter list.
Duplicate method parameter specified.
Invalid parameter name specified.
More than 200 string properties (*property={value})are being used for one CREATE statement.
Unable to convert VARIANT data type to PLB data type variable.
Invalid variant type specified for VARIANT object create. This error can also occur when a SETPROP of the VARTYPE property for a VARIANT object specifies a $VT_ARRAY value.
The window specified as a parent window is invalid when using the PARENTWIN property. The window operand for the PARENTWIN property cannot have a window type of MODAL or MODELESS.
Invalid argument requested for an EVENTINFO or EVENTREG.
No more than ten (10) nested collection name references are allowed for an OLE object.
No more than one hundred (100) collection index reference strings are allowed for an OLE object.
Null collection name reference is invalid for an OLE object.
Method does not exist for AUTOMATION interface.
Collection name reference does not exist for an OLE object.
Unable to invoke a method for an OLE object. Additional error data is not available. Possible causes could be an indeterminate number of reasons.
Collection index reference is invalid for OLE object.
The number of parameters is different from the number of arguments accepted by the method or property.
One of the parameters is not a valid variant type.
The OLE application has caused an exception error. Information concerning the exception error may be available by using the GETINFO EXCEPTION statement.
The specified member (method/property) does not exist or the operation tried to set the value of a read-only property.
This implementation of the IDispatch interface does not support named arguments.
One of the arguments could not be coerced to the required type.

One of the parameter DISPIDs being specified is invalid for the method. An 'ARG:' extended error data should indicate the first argument that contains the error. The 'ARG:' extended data is either presented in the error dialog or appended to the error variable for a TRAP operation.

One or more of the arguments contained invalid data type that could not be coerced into the required type format. The index within the argument list of the first parameter with the incorrect type is supplied as 'ARG:' extended data. The 'ARG:' extended data is either presented in the error dialog or appended to the error variable for a TRAP operation.

The member being invoked interprets string arguments according to the LCID, and the LCID is not recognized. If the LCID is not needed to interpret arguments, this error should not occur. LCID refers to 'Locale Identifier'. This specifies language requirements to member operations.
A required parameter was omitted.
An OLE object can not be created.
Runtime does NOT support OLE
Unable to establish storage id because more than 300 OLE objects have been created.
Unable to establish OLE form setup requirements.
Unable to create OLE container object because of invalid class or required interfaces are not available.

Unable to create OLE control object because of invalid class or required interfaces are not available. The Windows Extended error code is provided when it is available to be reported. In this case, the WINERR value in an extended OLE error that can help to identify the cause of the error.
CLASSID was not specified.

Invalid event specified for a NETOBJECT or NETCONTROL.

The client version does not support the STREAM instruction.
A GPF error has occurred in a Windows OS function while executing a PL/B method.
OS error occurred while locking the data file. This error should not occur unless the OS is failing.
Unable to re-open file.

I/O operation attempted on an unopened file.
Insufficient file handles available to PREP/OPEN specified file.
The path and filename size is too large to be placed into an AAM or ISI header during a PREPARE instruction.
During a PREPARE instruction, the text file name without a path is larger than 47 characters.

During a PREPARE instruction, ext file name that may or may not include pathing information is larger than 47 characters that is too large to be placed into an AAM or ISI header. If pathing information is included, the user may want to use a NOPATH keyword on an AFILE/IFILE declaration to prevent the path information from being placed into an AAM or ISI header.

Insufficient access rights or disk resources. During PREP, insufficient write or create privileges for the directory. During I/O, insufficient write privileges for the file/directory or file space full. Also, this error can occur when the OS IO (network/file) is unstable resulting in unknown/unexpected OS errors. For this error, the user should note/report any additional information which includes error subcodes and/or OS Error codes like WINERR for the Windows OS.
Unable to locate the file referenced by the CLOSE operation. Occurs if a file was deleted between the OPEN and CLOSE operations.

Unable to PREP/OPEN the requested file. Insufficient memory available for requested file buffer size. Insufficient rights/privileges (write access) to the directory or file space full. Attempt to OPEN a read only file in SHARE/EXCLUSIVE mode.
Invalid file specification.
The OPEN operation for an IFILE is using the same file name for the ISI and TXT files.
The PREPARE operation for an IFILE is using the same file name for the ISI and TXT files.
The OPEN operation for an AFILE is using the same file name for the AAM and TXT files.
The PREPARE operation for an AFILE is using the same file name for the AAM and TXT files.
The Windows OS data was unreliable when checking for same files while performing a OPEN operation for an IFILE. Consider using the PLBWIN_QNAME runtime keyword.
The Windows OS data was unreliable when checking for same files while performing a PREPARE operation for an IFILE. Consider using the PLBWIN_QNAME runtime keyword.
The Windows OS data was unreliable when checking for same files while performing a OPEN operation for an AFILE. Consider using the PLBWIN_QNAME runtime keyword.
The Windows OS data was unreliable when checking for same files while performing a PREPARE operation for an AFILE. Consider using the PLBWIN_QNAME runtime keyword.
Invalid sector number in WRITAB instruction. Either beyond End Of File or negative access number less than -4.

Invalid record length for a PREP instruction. The record length is zero or greater than the maximum allowed record size. This error can also occur if a file variable BUFFER/FIXED/VAR keyword value is greater than the maximum allowed record size. The maximum allowed record size can not exceed 65533.
During a PREPARE instruction, the file variable BUFFER keyword size is too large.
During a PREPARE instruction, the file variable FIXED keyword size is too large.
During a PREPARE instruction, the file variable VAR keyword size is too large.
During a PREPARE instruction, the record size specified for an IFILE PREP is invalid.
During a PREPARE instruction, the ecord size specified for an AFILE PREP is invalid.
The key length is either zero, greater than the maximum, or greater than record length.
No key specifications defined.
Invalid key syntax.
Invalid key specification entry values.
Keys overlap.
Too many key specifications used.
Invalid primary option syntax.
Invalid primary entry values.
Too many 'P' options.
Obsolete file format. SUNINDEX or SUNAAMDX the file with the correct version of the utility.

A NULL key is invalid for an ISAM WRITE/INSERT operation. This error can also occur for an Isam WRITE/INSERT operation when no key is specified and the IFILE being used does not have key location specifications identified.
Key used in ISAM operation is longer than allowed for file.
Invalid method variable in FILEIO operation.
Invalid OPEN or PREP mode value,
The EOR type specified by the MODE={value} bitmap value indicates an end of record type that is not the same as the end of record that was found in the AFILE/IFILE/FILE text file being accessed.
The MODE={value} bitmap value contains an undefined open mode definition.
The MODE={value} bitmap value contains an undefined EOR type definition. This error occurs when more than one EOR type is specified by the value.
A Windows runtime attempted to open a Unix index file or a Unix runtime attempted to open a Windows index file.
Attempt to tab across the sector boundary.
Standard file open or prep dialog was canceled.
FILELIST error.

FILELIST MFD type error. All files declared in a FILELIST must be opened either as a managed (MFD) file or opened as non-managed file. It is not valid to mix managed and non-managed files in the same FILELIST.
FILELIST MFD invalid for SUNDM. All of the files declared for a FILELIST must be under the control of the same SUNDM.
FILELIST requires same FIXED record length. When using FIXED length records, all files in a FILELIST must be declared or created with the same record length.

FILELIST file must be FIXED record type. All files in the FILELIST must be declared or created with FIXED length records specified. Mixing FIXED and VARIABLE length records in a FILELIST is not allowed.

FILELIST requires VARIABLE record type. All files in the FILELIST must be declared or created with VARIABLE length records specified. Mixing FIXED and VARIABLE length records in a FILELIST is not allowed.

FILELIST file record length is invalid. When using VARIABLE length records, the primary or first file in the FILELIST must have a record length less than or equal to any of the secondary files in the FILELIST.

FILELIST file requires valid key specifications. It is invalid to execute a FILELIST DELETE, UPDATE, or WRITE operation when using an AFILE/IFILE opened without key specification data available for an ISAM file.

FILELIST file key specifications not present in ISAM file. It is not possible to determine the key specifications from the ISAM file. The ISAM file must be re-indexed or prepared using valid key specifications.

FILELIST file invalid for direct operations. Individual AFILE/IFILE file variables for a FILELIST cannot be used in a DELETE, INSERT, UPDATE, or WRITE operation. The AFILE/IFILE file variables can only be used to DELETE, UDPATE, and WRITE using the FILELIST label reference.
FILELIST file text file mismatch detected. One of the files in a FILELIST is using a text data file that is different from the primary or first file in the FILELIST.

An IFILE included in a FILELIST was generated using the alternate primary key specification ("P{type}"{col}{func}{'string'}") option. The user should re-index the ISI file and use the primary key specification (P{nn}{= | #}{c}) option.
The primary file of the FILELIST is an IFILE and it is declared to use the 'Pn=x' option. This error insures that data file records can be accessed by key for an IFILE primary file.
A file in a FILELIST is not opened with the same format as the primary file. All files in a FILELIST must either be opened using the 9.0x format or the 8.7x format.
It is invalid to have more than one file variable in a FILELIST opened to the same ISI/AAM file.
CPU runtime running on a networked machine.
File OPEN/PREP in EXCLUSIVE mode denied, file busy. Specified file is already in EXCLUSIVE mode use by another process.
DELETE, INSERT, UPDATE, or WRITE operation attempted on a file opened in READ mode.
A TRANSACTION error occurred. This error can occur during any file I/O statement under a transaction.
During a TRANSACTION, memory allocation failed.
During a TRANSACTION, unable to get an EOF.
During a TRANSACTION, the EOF has moved.
During a TRANSACTION, unable to lock for commit.
During a TRANSACTION, read verify failed.
During a TRANSACTION, IO error on commit.
During a TRANSACTION, maximum read gaps seen.
During a TRANSACTION, IO error on flush.
During a TRANSACTION, file size violation.
When a 'TRANSACTION START' transaction is active, the file variable(s) used in the I/O instruction encountering the I27 error must be included in the 'TRANSACTION START' list of file variables.

A runtime dead lock time out has occurred. The runtime time has waited in an implied FILEPI lock longer than the number of seconds specified by the PLBWIN_DEADLOCKTIMEOUT keyword. The user applications should be evaluated to determine what files are being locked in one application versus what files are being locked in a second application at the point where the error has occurred.
Error returned during a FPOSITA or REPOSITA instruction.
During a FPOSITA or REPOSITA, the AAM index position data received from a SUNDM data manager is too large for the FPOSITA output variable.
During a FPOSITA or REPOSITA, the output index DIM variable is too small for the FPOSITA data.
During a FPOSITA or REPOSITA, key data is required.
During a FPOSITA or REPOSITA, the input AAM index position data is too small and cannot restores the AAM index position.
During a FPOSITA or REPOSITA, key data must be provided.
During a FPOSITA or REPOSITA, the input AAM index position data variable cannot be a null variable.
During a FPOSITA or REPOSITA, the input AAM index position data variable cannot be a null variable.
During a FPOSITA or REPOSITA, the SUNDM data manager that is being accessed does not support the FPOSITA and REPOSITA instructions.
Error returned while trying to delete a file during a CLOSE operation.
Unable to perform requested ERASE or RENAME operation. The file to be renamed was not found. Illegal global/wildcard naming convention used (i.e., asterisks or question marks).
WEOF statement was unable to set the file to the requested length.
Error processing SNDFILE.
While processing a SNDFILE, invalid for sound file.
While processing a SNDFILE, not enough memory to play sound.
Update file position is invalid.
Update of a compressed file is not allowed.
An operating system file io function has caused an error while the runtime is attempting to validate a file size in support of the PLBWIN_XPIO keyword.
ISAM tree data is invalid.
Data for the ISI tree structure is invalid when an ISI key sector is being de-allocated and added to the free sector list. The ISI data structure may be corrupt.
A sector retrieved from the ISI free sector list has an invalid free sector ID. The ISI data structure may be corrupt.
An invalid DDR sector ID in the ISI tree has been encountered while processing through the DDR sector list to remove a single Data Record Number.
An invalid DDR sector ID in the ISI tree has been encountered while reading the next sequential sector in the DDR sector list.
Valid READ or WRITE operation required prior to an INSERT operation. (Also see the PLBWIN_QNAME keyword.)
Invalid data file for INSERT operation. Data file for the INSERT operation is not the same as the data file for the preceding READ or WRITE operation. (Also see the PLBWIN_QNAME keyword.)
Valid READ required prior to an UPDATE, DELETE, READKG, or READKGP operation. Also occurs when a read current (a read with null key) is not preceded by a valid read.
Internal AAM write error (system error).
Invalid match criteria on AAM READ operation. Attempt to READ without the non-blank, non-wildcard minimum bytes required.
Illegal key field on AAM READ operation. Key field number is greater than the number of keys specified at file creation. Verify that the field number in all key are valid.

No corresponding record in text file for specified key. Either a text record was deleted without deleting all secondary indices or a file erroneously points to an Invalid portion of the data file (system error). An I44 error can also occur with a random read if the data has been deleted.
Error while accessing the .AAM key file for read, position, and write operations.
Insufficient information for a valid AAM READ. A READ using a free form key must contain three contiguous non-blank, non-wildcard characters.

Record length exceeds the declared buffer size for the FILE. Record written larger than declared BUFFER/FIX/FIXED size (256 byte default). Also, INSERT attempted with an invalid associated data record length.
The IFILE is declared for FIXED records and the record length being inserted is different than the IFILE fixed record length.
The IFILE is declared for VARIABLE or COMPRESSED records and the record length being inserted is greater than the buffer allocated for the IFILE.
The AFILE is declared for FIXED records and the record length being inserted is different than the AFILE fixed record length
The AFILE is declared for VARIABLE or COMPRESSED records and the record length being inserted is greater than the buffer allocated for the AFILE
Null keys specified in AAM PREP operation.
Key specification error in AAM PREPARE operation. Key specified was greater than the defined record length or the maximum key length.
Inserted item overstored an existing record.
Non-ISAM WRITE on ISAM file. Sequential write against an IFILE.
An ISAM WRITE operation has failed because a DRN (data record number) could cause data in the text data file to be overwritten.
A data record number retrieved from an ISI deleted data record map is invalid.
A data record position, determined from the ISI file, points into the TXT data file before the actual end of file position.
The file position for this INSERT or UPDATE operation points to a deleted record. MS-DOS SHARE utility has not been loaded.
Too many AAM key specifications given for an AAM read operation.
Attempt to write duplicate key to IFILE declared as NODUP.
The ISI file size is invalid.
The OS reported EOF size is shorter than the expected ISI file size.

The record data last READ for an AFILE/IFILE variable in the FILELIST has been changed before a FILELIST UPDATE/DELETE operation was performed. This failure indicates that multiple users are changing data records for a file without the use of FILEPI or record locking.
The record to be read is past the end of file when attempting to sync the primary FILELIST file with a secondary file in the FILELIST that was last read.
The text file data record has been changed after the last read operation and before the DELETE/UPDATE FILELIST operation has been executed.
The key required for the FILELIST file io operation can not be found.
Unable to read ISAM sector.
Unable to write ISAM sector.
ISAM file structure fault. Reindex the file.
ISAM tree stack underflow (system error).
Invalid Data Record Number for ISAM DELETE.
Attempt to UPDATE a compressed file.
Invalid record number for Isam WRITE/INSERT. This error indicates a problem in the ISI file Deleted Data Record (DDR) sectors.
Invalid Deleted Data Record pointer value.
Invalid number of pointers in current Deleted Data Record sector.
Invalid number of pointers in next Deleted Data Record sector.
Attempted to write record longer than specified record length.

Invalid record number specified in FILE DELETE. User has specified a record number that does not exist. Also, occurs when a -1, -2, -3, or -4 is specified as record number or when the data items are shorter than the record length.
Unable to lock record before operation.
Record locking requested and runtime does not support record locking.

When using the simple syntax form, the error subcode is the OS error code values as described in the IO Error Subcodes section. When using the enhanced syntax form, error subcodes provide additional information.
During an enhanced COPYFILE instruction, unable to open the {source} file.
During an enhanced COPYFILE instruction, unable to open or create the {dest} file.
During an enhanced COPYFILE instruction, COPYFILE is already active. The application must use the COPYNEXT or COPYCANCEL to finish the previous COPYFILE.
During an enhanced COPYFILE instruction, out of memory.
During an enhanced COPYFILE instruction, COPYNEXT cannot be executed until an enhanced copy action is started using a COPYFILE instruction.
During an enhanced COPYFILE instruction, unable to retrieve file attributes for the {source} file.
During an enhanced COPYFILE instruction, unable to retrieve file attributes for the {source} file.
During an enhanced COPYFILE instruction, unable to retrieve file attributes for the {dest} file.
During an enhanced COPYFILE instruction, an unexpected protocol message has been detected communicating with SUNDM or PLBSERVE.
During an enhanced COPYFILE instruction, a failure occurred while reading a data file.
During an enhanced COPYFILE instruction, a failure occurred while writing a data file.
During an enhanced COPYFILE instruction, a version for the client or data manager does not support enhanced COPYFILE.
During an enhanced COPYFILE instruction, unable to log onto the SUNDM data manager for the {source} file.
During an enhanced COPYFILE instruction, unable to log onto the SUNDM data manager for the {dest} file.
During an enhanced COPYFILE instruction, communications error occurred on the {source} side.
During an enhanced COPYFILE instruction, communications error occurred on the {dest} side.
During an enhanced COPYFILE instruction, the client or SUNDM data manager does not support FINDDIR operations.
During an enhanced COPYFILE instruction, unable to log onto the specified data manager.
During an enhanced COPYFILE instruction, communications error communicating with the PLBCLIENT or SUNDM data manager.
During an enhanced COPYFILE instruction, an unexpected protocol message type was encountered while communicating with the PLBCLIENT or SUNDM data manager.
The data file size larger than ( 2GB - 65535 ) is not allowed when Windows 98/ME OS types are being used.
2GB file size error has been detected using IFILE header data when opened with fixed length records.
2GB file size error has been detected using IFILE header data when opened with variable length records.
2GB file size error has been detected for a file variable accessing the data file directly.

WEOF attempted to shorten a file and the file could not be shortened. This error occurs if the PL/B runtime does not support the ability to truncate a data file. Contact the Sunbelt Technical Support if this error occurs.

Inconsistent FCB parameters on text file seek (system error). Also, this error can occur when the OS IO (network/file) is unstable resulting in unknown/unexpected OS errors. For this error, the user should note/report any additional information which includes error subcodes and/or OS Error codes like WINERR for the Windows OS.
A problem occurred while communicating with the SUNDM server task.
Insufficient memory to perform SUNDM server operations.
SUNDM unable to start child task.
Invalid SUNFHSYS.DLL version used.
Bad message type encountered.
SUNDM not found. Verify hostname, portnum, and IP addresses.
Failed to start socket.
Bad IP address.
Socket creation failure.
Socket communication failure.
SUNDM time expiration error.
SUNDM connection count has been exceeded.
The PL/B runtime and the SUNDM data manager being accessed have versions that are incompatible.
The PL/B runtime has lost a connection to SUNDM while receiving a message.
An error has occurred because the SUNDM NT Service has been been paused and logons are not allowed.
Data received for a TCP/IP message is larger than expected.
An error has occurred because the SUNDM server is shutting down and logons are not allowed.

A program attempted to open a managed file on a primary data manager in a replication network. This error and subcode occurs when the primary data manager is waiting to synchronize the data during the startup processing with secondary data managers in the replication network.
A program is attempting to logon to a secondary data manager.
An error has been detected while trying to initiate or perform an operation for a managed file.
The version found in a '.MFD' file is invalid for use with this runtime.
The 'SUNFHSYS.DLL' version is invalid when used for managed file support with this runtime.
The number of controls and parameters in a READ list exceeds the available buffer size used for managed file operations.
The number of controls and parameters in a WRITE list exceeds the available buffer size used for managed file operations.
The runtime does not use encryption while the SUNDM data manager requires encryption. Verify encryption setup provided by the runtime executing the PL/B program that received the I82 error.

The LOGON ID used by the runtime is invalid for the Logon Id list used by the SUNDM data manager. User should contact the administrator who can setup or verify the current logon ids allowing access to SUNDM.

The current IP address used by the client workstation connecting to SUNDM is identified to be invalid by existing on a non-approved IP address list. The user should contact the administrator who can setup or verify the current workstation IP addresses that may access SUNDM.

The current IP address used by the client workstation connecting to SUNDM is not valid to access the data manager. The user should contact the administrator who can setup or verify the current workstation IP addresses that can access SUNDM.
SUNDM section security error. Contact the system administrator.
SUNDM is unable to access IP filtering list. Contact the system administrator.
SUNDM does not use encryption while the runtime is specifying encryption keys. Contact the system administrator to verify runtime encryption requirements to access SUNDM.
Compression/Decompression error occurred while processing a message for SUNDM.
Either the runtime or SUNDM requires encryption and one of the connecting processes does not provide the encryption capability.
Encryption is enabled and the key specified by the runtime to access SUNDM is not valid.
SEARCHPATH operations at the Data Manager are not enabled. Enable this feature using the DM_ALLOWPATH=ON Data Manager keyword.
The runtime is shutting down the Data Manager socket connection and a socket error is being ignored.

A PLB runtime has detected a WRITE operation to a SunDM data manager where a single DIM variable in the WRITE variable list has a size larger than 65,535 bytes. All individual DIM variables written to the Data Manager must have a size less than 65,536 bytes. Otherwise, the write results would be indeterminate without this error.

The SunDM Data Manager has encountered an invalid WRITE data variable identifier. The intent of this error is to eliminate indeterminate write results if the write data stream has an invalid format. One scenario that can cause this error is when a 9.8 or earlier runtime version attempts to WRITE a DIM variable with a data size larger than 65,535 bytes.

A PLB runtime has detected a READ operation to a 9.8 or older SunDM Data Manager version where a single DIM variable in the READ variable list has a physical size larger than 65,535 bytes. All individual DIM variables being used for a READ from the Data Manager must have a size less than 65,536 bytes. Otherwise, the read results could be indeterminate without this error.

The SunDM Data Manager has encountered a READ operation where a single DIM variable in the READ variable list is larger than 65,535 bytes and the amount of data to be returned to the PLB runtime is larger than 65,535 bytes. All individual DIM variables being used for a READ from the Data Manager must have a size less than 65,536 bytes. Otherwise, the read results would be indeterminate without this error. Please note, a READ operation to a Data Manager 9.8A or new Data Manager can execute without this I82 error only if the data size to be returned is less than 65,535 bytes.

A PLB runtime has detected READ operation data as received from a Data Manager where the data size to be stored in a PLB INTEGER is too large and cannot be stored into the INTEGER without overflowing resulting in UDA corruption. The most likely cause of this error can be when a 9.8A or newer PLB runtime is accessing a 9.8 or older Data Manager and a DIM variable with a size larger than 65,535 is followed by an INTEGER in the READ variable list.

A PLB runtime has detected READ operation data as received from a Data Manager where the data size to be stored in a PLB FORM is too large and cannot be stored into the FORM without overflowing resulting in UDA corruption. The most likely cause of this error can be when a 9.8A or newer PLB runtime is accessing a 9.8 or older Data Manager and a DIM variable with a size larger than 65,535 is followed by an FORM in the READ variable list.

A PLB runtime has detected READ operation data as received from a Data Manager where the data size to be stored in a PLB DIM is too large and cannot be stored into the DIM without being truncated. If this error was not generated, the READ results could be wrong and\or indeterminate.

During a SQLIO operation, an invalid PLB column type value has been encountered in the Sun_Sqlio_Columns system table. The type must be a value defined as 0=DIM, 1=FORM, or 2=INTEGER.

During a SQLIO operation, an invalid PLB column size value has been encountered in the Sun_Sqlio_Columns system table. The field length must be defined as follows: DIM ( size <= 65534 ), FORM ( size <= 32 ), or INTEGER ( size <= 8 ). Also occurs when the SQL_IDENTITY type is specified for <sql_type> and the <unique_col> is not set to be unique in the Sun_Sqlio_Columns system table. The field size of a SQL_NCHAR or SQL_NCHAR_T column is not a multiple of 2 when the schema column is created.
During a SQLIO operation, an invalid PLB scale value has been encountered in the Sun_Sqlio_Columns system table. The PLB field scale value must in the range of ( -1 <= scale <= 32 ).

During a SQLIO operation, an invalid SQL column type has been encountered in the Sun_Sqlio_Columns system table. The SQL column type value cannot be less than zero and cannot be greater than the maximum number of SQL types support for SQLIO operations.
During a SQLIO operation, an invalid zero fill value has been encountered in the Sun_Sqlio_Columns system table. The zero file value cannot be less than zero.
During a SQLIO operation, a column offset value encountered in the Sun_Sqlio_Columns system table overlaps with another column offset value. Column offsets may not overlap.
